definitions.definition: a type of soft flat hat with a peak (= a hard curved part sticking out in front). Caps are worn especially by men and boys, often as part of a uniform

examples.text: to put on/take off a cap

definitions.definition: a soft hat that fits closely and is worn for a particular purpose
a soft hat with a square flat top worn by some university teachers and students at special ceremonies
a cap given to somebody who is chosen to play for a school, country, etc.; a player chosen to play for their country, etc.

examples.text: He won his first cap *(= was first chosen to play)* for England against France.
There are three new caps in the side.

definitions.definition: a cover or top for a pen, bottle, etc.

examples.text: The bottle has a screw cap.

definitions.definition: an artificial cover for a damaged tooth

examples.text: He needed four caps for his teeth after the accident.

definitions.definition: the top of a mountain or a wave

examples.text: Purple mist sat below the snowy mountain caps.

definitions.definition: an upper limit on an amount of money that can be spent or borrowed by a particular institution or in a particular situation

examples.text: The government has placed a cap on local council spending.

definitions.definition: a small paper container with explosive powder inside it, used especially in toy guns
a rubber or plastic device that a woman places inside her vagina before having sex to prevent sperm from entering the womb and making her pregnant
an action that you can be proud of
to ask somebody for something, especially money, in a very polite way that makes you seem less important

examples.text: There’s no way he’ll go cap in hand to his brother.

definitions.definition: if you feel that a remark applies to you, you should accept it and take it as a warning or criticism

examples.text: I didn’t actually say that you were lazy, but if the cap fits…

wordOrigin: Old English cæppe ‘hood’, from late Latin cappa, perhaps from Latin caput ‘head’.
